alert.note: Alert for Clearwater; Idaho; Lemhi (Idaho) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Missoula (Western Montana and Central Idaho)
info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued August 18 at 10:44AM MDT by NWS Missoula
info.description: ...INCREASED RISK OF HEAVY RAIN SUNDAY AND MONDAY, WITH POTENTIAL SIGNIFICANT FLOODING IMPACTS TO FLOOD PRONE AREAS, INCLUDING BURN SCARS AND URBAN AREAS... Atmospheric moisture associated with Hurricane Hilary will move across the Great Basin into central Idaho by Sunday afternoon. Thunderstorms will develop during the afternoon and will be capable of producing heavy rainfall, with localized rainfall rain rates in excess of 2 to 3 inches per hour. Flood prone areas, including burn scars and urban areas, will be at risk for rock, mudslide, and debris flows. Ultimately, hydrologic impacts will strongly depend on the track and strength of the remnants of Hurricane Hilary. Given this uncertainty, a wide array of rainfall amounts and potential impacts currently exist. The risk of heavy rain continues Monday as moisture increases, with precipitable water values (a measure of moisture in the atmosphere), reaching potentially historic values. This airmass, combined with atmospheric forcing associated with the remnants of Hurricane Hilary, will set the stage for heavy rainfall and potential significant hydrologic impacts. Warm rain processes will lead to localized precipitation amounts of 1 to 3 inches. Again, our main concern will be centered across flood prone areas such as US Highway 95 between Grangeville and Riggins, the Salmon River corridor, US Highway 93 south of Salmon, and burn scars.
